title: Should I learn the trumpet or clarinet? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some really good answers here but I as someone that plays both trumpet and clarinet I’d like to speak about what’s hard about each of them. Trumpet: Stamina!!!!! - This is IMO the hardest challenge that the trumpet offers. Playing the trumpet is much more painful than most expect. You will often experience your ‘lip going’ due to pressing the trumpet into your lips, cutting off circulation and causing them to temporarily stop working. Often trumpet players will be able to identify other trumpet players by a small circular scar on the lips. Pitching - On the trumpet (and all other brass instruments) each combination of valves offers multiple notes. You adjust the tightness of your lips to determine which note is produced. If you aren’t precise with this or your lips are tired the note will note be clean. It may be ‘split’ where it seems briefly partway between two notes before you correct it or it may be mispitched producing entirely the wrong note. Most wind instruments require a ‘musical ear’ to some extent but the trumpet requires more pitching than most others. Clarinet: Pain: Holding the clarinet in your mouth involves folding your bottom lip in over your lower front teeth and resting the reed on top. This means that your teeth end up digging into the inside of your lower lip. Eventually you’ll build up a patch of dead skin there and it won’t become painful as fast but it never really stops completely. This doesn’t cut of circulation like it does with the trumpet so with a bit of grit you’ll still be able to play but it’s a much sharper pain. The Break: Clarinet fingering is for the most part fairly logical. More fingers is lower and as you take fingers off the note gets higher… sort of like a recorder. However…. Moving from a Bb in the stave to the B above involves quickly moving from only 2 fingers used to 9 fingers. This makes some fast passages extremely difficult! Construction: Most clarinets come in 5 pieces. You’ll need to put these pieces together each time you play then fit the ligature and reed to the mouthpiece (being careful not to damage your favourite reed!) Then when you’ve finished playing you’ll need to clean the inside and disassemble it again. Despite (and sometimes because) of these challenges both of these instruments are incredibly fun and rewarding to play and whichever you choose you’ll be learning a great instrument!

I like Dylan Quattro’s answer a lot. My opinion differs only in that I think all instruments are equally difficult to play well. It takes just as long to learn to play a clarinet well as it takes to play the trumpet well. Do not let that idea influence your thoughts. Clarinet is definitely not rather easily learned. Must be a trumpet player stating this ;) To emphasize the equal difficulty to learn any instrument I bring this video clip showing that even learning to play the triangle well it takes practice. An you thought anybody could play that!  As Dylan explained think more about the passion for the style and the kind of music you want to play. Where is you love? If you don’t have love for either instrument go and play saxophone.
